title: Standing Up To Fight The Bells
historical_context: This article discusses the implications of the Regional Bell Operating Companies (RBOCs) gaining access to the information services market following a court ruling that overturned previous restrictions. It reflects concerns about consumer privacy and monopolistic practices in the telecommunications industry during the early 1990s.
target_audience: Consumers, privacy advocates, telecommunications professionals, and those interested in regulatory issues.
short_summary: Knight Lightning warns against the potential abuses of consumer privacy and anti-competitive practices by Regional Bell Operating Companies (RBOCs) following a court ruling that allows them to enter the information services market. The article emphasizes the need for consumer advocacy and legislative support to protect privacy rights.
summary:
In 'Standing Up To Fight The Bells,' Knight Lightning articulates a pressing concern regarding the Regional Bell Operating Companies (RBOCs) and their newfound ability to enter the information services market. Following a court ruling that lifted restrictions imposed after the breakup of AT&T, the RBOCs now have the potential to exploit consumer data for profit, raising alarms about privacy violations and anti-competitive behavior. The author cites specific examples of how the RBOCs could misuse calling records to target consumers with unsolicited services, thereby infringing on personal privacy and undermining the competitive landscape of information services. 

The article calls for immediate action from consumers and legislators to support bills HR 3515 and S 2112, which aim to delay RBOC entry into the information services market until fair competition is established. Knight Lightning argues that without such measures, the RBOCs could leverage their monopolistic control to stifle competition, inflate prices, and ultimately dictate the information landscape available to consumers. The piece serves as both a warning and a rallying cry for consumer advocacy in the face of corporate monopolization.
